items.message:
River levels are falling on the Bristol Avon, Tetbury Avon, Sherston Avon and Dauntsey Brook.  Areas most at risk include the road at Reybridge..
Saturday is forecast to be mostly dry, however further rain over the next few days is likely to cause river levels to rise again.

We are monitoring rainfall and river levels, checking rivers for blockages and clearing debris from weed screens in the area.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

This message will be updated on Saturday evening, or sooner if the situation changes.

Flooding is expected in this area. This means properties are at risk of flooding.

Please take action to protect yourself and your property and monitor local weather and river conditions. Avoid contact with, walking or driving through flood water. Consider activating any property flood protection products you may have.

Environment Agency Flood Warning Officers set the river or tidal levels that have triggered this message. During industrial action this message has been automatically issued based on rising river or tidal levels.

This message will be updated by tomorrow, 12/11/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message: River and lake levels are expected to remain high on the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water due to recent rainfall. Areas most at risk include The Upper Derwent from Seathwaite to Derwent Water. Lake levels remain high at the Lodore gauge. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 05:00 PM on 11/11/2023.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Tamar, River Strat, River Neet, River Ottery, River Kensey

items.message:
River levels remain high following recent rainfall.  Unsettled weather is forecast to continue with rain over Saturday night, followed by heavy rain on Sunday, bringing a further risk of flooding from Sunday evening and overnight into Monday morning. 

Catchments are saturated, so river levels will remain high and respond to further rainfall. Flooding to low lying land and roads close to the River Tamar is possible.  

Monitor your local weather conditions and avoid using low lying footpaths or entering areas prone to flooding. Do not walk or drive through flood water. We have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages. We will be monitoring the situation and will issue updates by midday on Sunday or earlier if the situation changes.

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire
floodArea.riverOrSea: River Derwent, Sea Cut, River Hertford, Burniston Beck

items.message: River levels remain high on the upper river Derwent. Levels have now peaked and continue to fall slowly. Flooding of low lying land is possible in this area. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please take action to protect yourself and your property, and monitor local weather and river conditions. Avoid contact with, walking or driving through flood water. We continue to monitor the situation and will update this message at 9pm this evening (Saturday, 11th November 2023), or as the situation changes.

items.description: The tidal River Waveney from Ellingham to Breydon Water
items.message: This message has been issued because some flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely to continue throughout today, Saturday 11th November, and over the weekend.  High water levels are likely to last for the next few days.  This is due to a natural tide locking effect of the Broads river system and the recent rainfall.  We expect to see high water levels at Beccles Quay.  The weather forecast is for largely dry conditions today.  Frontal rain is forecast to bring widespread rain through Sunday evening and overnight into Monday with some of this potentially being heavy.  Flood water is dangerous.  Don't put yourself or others at risk.  We are closely monitoring the situation.  We will update this message on Sunday 12th November 2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The tidal River Yare from Thorpe St Andrew to Breydon Water
items.message: This message has been issued because some flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely to continue throughout today, Saturday 11th November, and over the weekend. items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Teign, River Bovey, River Lemon, River Kenn

items.message:
Flooding is possible overnight on Saturday, and into Sunday.
Recent rainfall falling on already saturated catchments in the River Teign area, has meant that the River Teign is now rising. We expect the river to remain high throughout Sunday, though no flooding to properties is forecast and flood warnings are not expected to be issued.
We expect flooding to affect Newton Abbot, Kingsteignton, Teignmouth, Shaldon, Bovey Tracey, Kings kerswell, Dawlish and Dawlish Warren, where levels suggest that there will be flooding to low lying land and roads, close to the river around 3am on Sunday morning.
We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for, and clearing, blockages in this location. This message will be updated on Sunday if and when the situation changes

For water levels on the River Tone and Currymoor Drain at Currymoor pumping station please refer to our website: Check For Flooding (check-for-flooding.service.gov.uk).

Water will enter Currymoor reservoir via Hookbridge spillway whilst the River Tone level exceeds 7.45 m.

We are utilising our pumping stations, including additional temporary pumps, as water levels allow. The Parrett Relief Channel is being used to evacuate the water away from the Parrett-Tone confluence.

Further rain, including heavy downpours, is forecast this week, therefore flooding remains possible over the next few days.

Please consider weather conditions, local water levels and your flood plan if you have one. Avoid using low lying footpaths, roads and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

Environment Agency Flood Warning Officers set the river or tidal levels that have triggered this message. During industrial action this message has been automatically issued based on rising river or tidal levels.

River levels are high but steady at the Cae Howel river gauge. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley.
River levels have peaked and will remain steady, with no further rise forecasted.
We are closely monitoring the situation.
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated by 10:00 on 12/11/23, or as the situation changes.

items.message: This message has been issued because flooding to riverside roads and footpaths will continue throughout today, Saturday 11th November, and over the weekend.  High water levels are likely to last for the next few days.  This is due to a natural tide locking effect of the Broads river system combined with the recent high rainfall.  We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry Road in Horning.  The weather forecast is for largely dry conditions today, Saturday 11th November.  Sunday morning is also forecast to be dry.  However, frontal rain is forecast to bring widespread rain through Sunday evening and overnight into Monday with some of this potentially being heavy.  Flood water is dangerous.  Don't put yourself or others at risk.  We are closely monitoring the situation.  We will update this message on Sunday 12th November 2023, or as the situation changes.

Saturday is forecast to be mostly dry, however further rain over the next few days is likely to cause river levels to rise again.

We are monitoring rainfall and river levels, checking rivers for blockages and clearing debris from weed screens in the area.

items.description: Dauntsey Brook at Dauntsey, Old Sodom Lane and The Green areas
items.message: More rain is forecast for the next few days which will cause river levels to rise again.

River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Crew Green river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent the river from Shrewsbury to Upper Arley. Locations that may be affected are White Abbey, Coalbrookdale, Ironbridge and Bridgnorth. River Severn  bankfull at White Abbey. Actual and Predicted Peaks:- Crew Green peaked at 5.28m last night, Montford peaked at 4.43m this morning, Welshbridge peaked at 2.27m this morning, Buildwas forecast to peak between 3.2m to 3.5m this evening, Bridgnorth forecast to peak between 2.4m to 2.7m on Sunday morning.   
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please avoid contact with flood water.  
This message will be updated by 10:00 on 12/11/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames for the Abingdon area
items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are high but steady on the River Thames as a result of recent heavy rain. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue, especially in the Abingdon area.  No further rainfall is forecast today 11/11/23, but heavy rainfall is expected overnight on Sunday 12/11/23 with low confidence over exact locations and timings. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow, 12/11/23, or as the situation changes.

Water levels in the Eastern Yar remain high. Water levels at Alverstone continue to fall, and water levels at Sandown are also falling slowly. Saturday should remain dry, which will allow water levels to continue to fall throughout the Eastern Yar catchment. Some rainfall, up to 10mm, is forecast for Sunday. However, Monday is currently forecast to be wet, with a further 15-20mm of rainfall forecast. The flooding will continue to affect low lying land in the coming days. Ditches around Fort Holiday Park Sandown will struggle to drain while river levels are high. If rain does affect the area then water levels will rise again, throughout the catchment. With the current forecast, water levels are likely to start rising at Alverstone during the early hours of Monday morning, and water levels are likely to start rising at Sandown on Monday. We are operating Bembridge sluice so that water is able to flow out to sea, between high tides. We continue to monitor the forecast. Avoid walking or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 13:00 on Sunday 12 November.

items.description: Minor Watercourses from Heighington to Dunston
items.message: Rainfall over the weekend in Heighington to Dunston area plus high ground water levels means that River levels will remain high for the next few days and possibly beyond. This will lead to flooding of low-lying land and roads close to the river. Our forecasts indicate that flooding inside properties isn't likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated online and on Floodline as the situation changes.

items.description: The River Waveney from Diss and the River Dove to Ellingham, including Bungay
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely today, Saturday 11th November.  River levels remain higher than normal and will be responsive to any further rainfall.  Areas most at risk are low lying roads and riverside areas around Diss, Eye, Harleston and Bungay.  The forecast is for largely dry conditions today.  Frontal rain is forecast to bring widespread rain through Sunday evening and overnight into Monday with some of this potentially being heavy.  Flood water is dangerous.  Don't put yourself or others at risk.  We are closely monitoring the situation.  We will update this message on Sunday 12th November 2023 or as the situation changes.

The Cuckmere River is high near Alfriston, but slowly falling. Elsewhere on the Cuckmere river levels are near normal. Minor flooding could continue to affect fields, rural roads, and gardens near Alfriston. Saturday should remain dry, but a small amount of rain (5-20mm) is forecast Sunday. River levels along the Cuckmere could rise Sunday, and generate minor flood impacts affecting fields, gardens and roads. Monday is currently forecast to be very wet. A further 20-30mm of rain is possible, which could potentially cause property flooding in Hellingly and Alfriston. With more rain forecast for Wednesday, the river might not return nearer to normal level until next weekend. The river will be sensitive to any additional rainfall over the rest of winter. Please plan to avoid driving through routes susceptible to flooding, including Mill Lane and Church Road, Hellingly, and North Street, Alfriston. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will likely re-issue this message Sunday or Monday 13/11/2023.

items.description: Hundred Foot Washes in Cambridgeshire and Norfolk

floodArea.riverOrSea: Old Bedford River, New Bedford River, Hundred Foot Drain, River Delph

items.message:
This information is correct as of 3:30pm on Saturday 11th November 2023. 

The causeway at Welney has approximately 4 centimetres of water on the road. There are currently no issues on the Sutton Gault causeway or the Earith causeway. Due to the uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places.

We will update this message by 8am tomorrow morning Sunday 12th November 2023.

The Western Rother is high near Fittleworth, but slowly falling. Elsewhere on the Western Rother, river levels are already near normal. Minor flood impacts could continue to affect fields, rural roads, and gardens near Fittleworth. Saturday should remain dry, but a small amount of rain (5-20mm) is forecast Sunday. River levels along the Western Rother could rise by a small amount Sunday, although no significant increase to flood risk is expected. However, Monday is currently forecast to be very wet. A further 20-30mm of rain is possible, which could potentially cause property flooding between Lodsbridge near Selham and Fittleworth. With more rain forecast for Wednesday, the river might not return nearer to normal level until next weekend. The river will be sensitive to any additional rainfall over the rest of winter. Early actions to reduce potential impacts at Lodsbridge and Fittleworth are encouraged. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will likely re-issue this message Sunday, or Monday 13/11/2023.

items.description: River Thames and tributaries in the Oxford area
items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are high but steady on the River Thames as a result of recent heavy rain. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue, especially in the Wolvercote and Botley areas.  No further rainfall is forecast today 11/11/23, but heavy rainfall is expected overnight on Sunday 12/11/23 with low confidence over exact locations and timings. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow, 12/11/23, or as the situation changes.

The Aldingbourne Rife is high but slowly falling. Flooding is thought to still be affecting the Tesco car park on Shripney Road, land and caravans at Riverside Caravan Centre and Rowan Park Caravan Park, and areas of Durban Road. Water will still affect fields near Shripney Lane and the A259. Saturday is forecast to remain dry. A small amount of rain (5-20mm) is possible Sunday. However a further 20-30mm of rain is forecast for Monday. River levels in Bersted are expected to rise again on Monday 13/11/2023, possibly by 20cm. River levels in Barnham could rise on both Sunday and Monday, with Sunday's rain potentially enough to cause isolated property flooding in Barnham. The Aldingbourne Rife might not return to normal until the end of November. Some roads will be affected by flood water, please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding, including Shripney Lane. We are running our pumps at Felpham and keeping grilles clear to help reduce the risk of flooding. We will update this message by 11:00 12/11/2023.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message:
For water levels on the River Yeo and the Drain at Huish Episcopi pumping station please refer to our website: Check For Flooding (check-for-flooding.service.gov.uk).
Flooding will affect the road from Langport to Muchelney if this level exceeds 7.3 m, the road from Muchelney to Long load if this level exceeds 7.86 and the road from Muchelney to Thorney if this level exceeds 7.93 m. 
We are utilising our pumping stations, as water levels allow. The Parrett Relief Channel is also being used to evacuate the water.
Further rain, including heavy downpours, is forecast this week, therefore flooding remains possible over the next few days.
Please consider weather conditions, local water levels and your flood plan if you have one. Avoid using low lying footpaths, roads and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

items.description: Sandown, Brading and Bembridge on the Eastern Yar
items.message: Water levels in the Eastern Yar remain high. Water levels at Sandown are falling slowly. Saturday should remain dry, which will allow water levels to continue to fall throughout the Eastern Yar catchment. Some rainfall, up to 10mm, is forecast for Sunday. However, Monday is currently forecast to be wet, with a further 15-20mm of rainfall forecast. Some rainfall is also forecast for Tuesday. The flooding will continue to affect low lying land and this is likely to continue in the coming days. Ditches around Fort Holiday Park, Sandown, will struggle to drain while river levels are high. If rain does affect the area then water levels will rise again, throughout the catchment. With the current forecast, water levels are likely to start rising at Sandown on Monday. We are operating Bembridge sluice so that water is able to flow out to the sea, between high tides. We continue to monitor the forecast. We will issue further advice if additional rainfall causes a significant rise in water level. The Flood Alert for the Eastern Yar remains in force.

The Combe Haven in Bulverhythe is high, but slowly falling. At Crowhurst, the Powdermill Stream is nearer to normal. Flooding will continue to affect Bexhill Road Recreation Ground in Bulverhythe. Minor flooding could continue to affect fields and rural roads. Saturday should remain dry, but a small amount of rain (5-20mm) is forecast Sunday. River levels along the Combe Haven could rise Sunday, and generate minor flood impacts affecting fields, gardens and roads. Monday is currently forecast to be very wet. A further 20-30mm of rain is possible, which could potentially cause property flooding in Crowhurst and Bulverhythe. With more rain forecast for Wednesday, the river might not return nearer to normal levels until next weekend. The river will be sensitive to any additional rainfall over the rest of winter. Flood protection products are recommended to be kept installed in Crowhurst, if you have them. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 13:00 12/11/2023.

The Aldingbourne Rife is high but slowly falling. Flooding is thought to still be affecting the Tesco car park on Shripney Road, land and caravans at Riverside Caravan Centre and Rowan Park Caravan Park, and areas of Durban Road. Water will still affect fields near Shripney Lane and the A259. Saturday is forecast to remain dry. A small amount of rain (5-20mm) is possible Sunday, which should only cause river levels to rise by a few centimetres. However, a further 20-30mm of rain is forecast for Monday. River levels are expected to continue to slowly fall until Monday 13/11/2023, when river levels are expected to rise again, possibly by 20cm. With the rest of November forecast to remain unsettled, the Aldingbourne Rife might not return to normal until the end of November. Some roads will be affected by flood water, please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding, including Shripney Lane. We are running our pumps at Felpham and keeping grilles clear to help reduce the risk of flooding. We will update this message by 11:00 12/11/2023.

items.description: Rivers Yeo and Parrett, downstream of Yeovil to Steart

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Parrett, River Yeo, Cary, Sowy, Kings Sedgemoor Drain

items.message:
Further rain, including heavy downpours, is forecast this week, therefore flooding remains possible over the next few days.
Areas most at risk include the Ilchester to Yeovilton road at the end of the runway, the Mudford to Limington road, the road and properties at the south end of Westover Trading Estate. 
We are utilising our pumping stations, including additional temporary pumps, as water levels allow. The Parrett Relief Channel is being used to evacuate the water away from the Parrett-Tone confluence.
Please consider weather conditions, local water levels and your flood plan if you have one. Avoid using low lying footpaths, roads and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
Environment Agency Flood Warning Officers set the river or tidal levels that have triggered this message. During industrial action this message has been automatically issued based on rising river or tidal levels.

The Aldingbourne Rife is high, but slowly falling. No flood impacts are currently thought to be occuring south of the A29 Shripney Road. Saturday is forecast to remain dry. A small amount of rain (5-20mm) is possible Sunday, which should only cause river levels to rise by a few centimetres. However, a further 20-30mm of rain is forecast for Monday. River levels are expected to continue to slowly fall until Monday 13/11/2023, when river levels are expected to rise again. With the rest of November forecast to remain unsettled, the Aldingbourne Rife might not return to normal until the end of November. Some roads may be affected, please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We are running our pumps at Felpham and keeping grilles clear to help reduce the risk of flooding. We will re-issue this message if the risk of property flooding increases.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message: Flooding is possible through the early hours of Sunday morning. Catchments are wet and expected to respond to sustained rainfall through late Saturday evening. Expected levels suggest that there will be flooding to low lying land and roads close to the river. We expect the river to remain high throughout Sunday, though no flooding to properties is currently forecast.  Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions.  We are monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages. This message will be updated if the situation changes.

items.description: Outlying villages on the Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: This message has been issued because of the ongoing impact and continued risk of flooding to homes and businesses, which will  continue throughout today, Saturday 11th November, and over the weekend.  High water levels are likely to last for the next few days.  This is due to a natural tide locking effect of the Broads river system combined with the recent high rainfall.  Areas most at risk are Ridlington, Briggate, Honing, East Rushton, Dilham, Sutton, Catfield Common, Hickling, Potter Heigham, Ludham, Bastwick, Martham, Damgate and Billockby, and the A149 and A1062 roads.  The weather forecast is for largely dry conditions today, Saturday 11th November, and also for the morning of Sunday 12th November.  However, frontal rain is forecast to bring widespread rain through Sunday evening and overnight into Monday with some of this potentially being heavy.  Flood water is dangerous.  Don't put yourself or others at risk.  We are closely monitoring the situation.  We will update this message on Sunday 12th November 2023, or as the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Tamar, River Lyd, River Thrushel

items.message:
River levels remain high following recent rainfall.  Unsettled weather is forecast to continue with rain over Saturday night, followed by heavy rain on Sunday, bringing a further risk of flooding from Sunday evening and overnight into Monday morning.

Catchments are saturated, so river levels will remain high and respond to further rainfall. Flooding to low lying land and roads close to the River Tamar is possible. 

Monitor your local weather conditions and avoid using low lying footpaths or entering areas prone to flooding. Do not walk or drive through flood water. We have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages. We will be monitoring the situation and will issue updates by midday on Sunday or earlier if the situation changes.

Flooding is possible in this area.

Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. Avoid using low lying footpaths or entering areas prone to flooding. Start acting on your flood plan if you have one.

Environment Agency Flood Warning Officers set the river or tidal levels that have triggered this message. During industrial action this message has been automatically issued based on rising river or tidal levels.

For water levels on the River Tone and Currymoor Drain at Currymoor pumping station please refer to our website: Check For Flooding (check-for-flooding.service.gov.uk).
Water will enter Currymoor reservoir via Hookbridge spillway whilst the River Tone level exceeds 7.45 m. 
We are utilising our pumping stations, including additional temporary pumps, as water levels allow. The Parrett Relief Channel is being used to evacuate the water away from the Parrett-Tone confluence. 
Further rain including heavy downpours are forecast this week, therefore flooding remains possible over the next few days.
Please consider weather conditions, local water levels and your flood plan if you have one. Avoid using low lying footpaths, roads and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
Environment Agency Flood Warning Officers set the river or tidal levels that have triggered this message. During industrial action this message has been automatically issued based on rising river or tidal levels.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the West of Dorset
items.message: Groundwater levels have responded to the intense rainfall over the last few weeks, with the borehole at Kingston Russell rising to 115 metres overnight. The more westerly communities on the Chalk in Dorset, including those along the South Winterbourne Valley, Beaminster and Hooke will start to experience issues with septic tanks and roads may become flooded. Levels are expected to continue rising until at least the end of next week. You can monitor groundwater levels at the Kingston Russell borehole on the Check-for-Flooding.gov.uk website. Further heavy rainfall is expected in the middle of next week. Please avoid driving through flood water as the bow wave can flood nearby properties and can seriously damage your engine. If there is no alternative please drive very slowly to minimise damage. If you have property flood resilience measures such as pumps, air brick covers or flood barriers, you should consider putting them in place now. This message will be updated on Monday.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Upper Og Valley
items.message:
Groundwater levels have responded to recent rainfall and have risen at our observation borehole in Draycot Foliat in the Og Valley area. Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and remain at a level where communities may be affected by flooding from groundwater over the coming days. Groundwater levels in the area are currently stable but remain responsive to rainfall. No rainfall is forecast today 11/11/23, but heavy rainfall is expected overnight on Sunday into Monday, with the weather becoming more settled later in the week.
Groundwater level will continue to remain high and may still impact low lying gardens and cellars. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer.
We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message by 18/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

Flooding is possible in this area.

Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. Avoid using low lying footpaths or entering areas prone to flooding. Start acting on your flood plan if you have one.

Environment Agency Flood Warning Officers set the river or tidal levels that have triggered this message. During industrial action this message has been automatically issued based on rising river or tidal levels.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Cranborne Chase area
items.message:
Groundwater levels have risen above 99 metres at the Woodyates borehole, Levels are forecast to rise quite steeply for the next 48 hours at least. Flooding of minor roads is possible at this level. Some septic tanks are likely to fail with a continued rise in level. Areas most likely to be affected are the Vale of Allen, including Sixpenny Handley and the Chalke Valley. 
Householders with property level protection measures such as pumps, flood barriers and air brick covers should put them in place now.
Motorists should avoid driving through flood water as the bow wave can damage homes and car engines.
This message will be updated tomorrow, Monday

The River Lavant is high, following an exceptionally wet October and start to November. River levels are stable and only minimal flooding impacts are currently expected to affect fields. Saturday should remain dry, but a small amount of rain (5-20mm) is forecast Sunday, with more rain on Monday (20-30mm). The River Lavant might rise by 10-20cm on Sunday, which might be enough for minor flood impacts to affect Sheepwash Lane, Pook Lane, and the Green in East Lavant. With more rain forecast for Wednesday, the river might not begin to fall until next weekend. The river will be sensitive to any additional rainfall over the rest of winter. Some roads could be affected by flood water, please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding including Sheepwash Lane. If you see a blockage affecting the flow in the river, please call our incident hotline on 0800 80 70 60. We are managing structures in Westhampnett to operate the River Lavant Flood Alleviation Scheme to reduce the flood risk on the River Lavant. We will re-issue this message if the risk of flooding increases again.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the South Wiltshire Downs - The Dene
items.message:
The level at the nearby Terraces, Fonthill borehole has risen to 116 metres above sea level.  Flooding to properties from groundwater in the Dene Valley is now expected. The stream will remain high for several days. Ensure that pumps are operational and that other precautions such as airbrick covers and flood boards are in place. Avoid driving through flood water as the bow wave will cause properties to flood. 
Further rainfall is expected on Wednesday and at the beginning of next week which will keep levels high. A high pressure system may bring a brief respite from about the 15th; this may provide an opportunity to replenish any property level resilience measures.
This message will be updated on Tuesday.

items.description: Groundwater flooding for the South Winterbourne Valley
items.message:
The level at the nearby Kingston Russell borehole has risen to 116 metres above sea level.  Flooding to properties from groundwater in the South Winterbourne Valley is now expected. The Winterbourne will remain high for several days. Ensure that pumps are operational and that other precautions such as airbrick covers and flood boards are in place. Avoid driving through flood water as the bow wave will cause properties to flood. 
Further rainfall is expected on Wednesday and at the beginning of next week which will keep levels high. A high pressure system may bring a brief respite from about the 15th; this may provide an opportunity to replenish any property level resilience measures.
This message will be updated on Tuesday.

Flooding is possible in this area.

Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. Avoid using low lying footpaths or entering areas prone to flooding. Start acting on your flood plan if you have one.

floodArea.county: Bath and North East Somerset, North Somerset, Somerset
floodArea.riverOrSea: Congresbury Yeo, Cheddar Yeo, River Axe, River Banwell

items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have peaked and will remain steady, with no further rise forecasted.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  Further showers are possible over the next 48 hours.  
We continue to monitor the situation
